revision.comment: /* Primates */clean up from page move, replaced: [[taxonomic]] → [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''g'' factor in non-humans}}The [[g factor (psychometrics)|''g'' factor]], or general factor, of [[intelligence]] is a [[psychometric]] construct that summarizes observed correlations between an individual’s scores on various measures of [[cognitive abilities]]. First described in [[humans]], a ''g'' factor has since been identified in a number of non-human species.<ref name="Reader">Reader, S. M., Hager, Y., & Laland, K. N. (2011). The evolution of primate general and cultural intelligence. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences, 366(1567), 1017-1027.</ref>
The amount of variance explained by ''g'' varies widely among species. The reasons for this are not clear; J. P. Rushton has attempted to place g in an evolutionary frame of reference.<ref>Rushton, J. P. (2004). Placing intelligence into an evolutionary framework or how ''g'' fits into the r–K matrix of life-history traits including longevity.Intelligence, 32(4), 321-328.</ref> Non-human [[model organisms|models]] of ''g'' have been used in [[genetics|genetic]]<ref name="Plomin">Plomin, R. (2001). The genetics of ''g'' in human and mouse. Nature Reviews Neuroscience, 2(2), 136-141.</ref> and [[neurological]]<ref name="Anderson">Anderson, B. (2000). The ''g'' factor in non-human animals. The nature of intelligence, (285), 79.</ref> research on intelligence to help understand the mechanisms behind variation in ''g''.
==Methods==
Most measures of ''g'' in humans, including most [[IQ]] tests, rely heavily on [[language]] and verbal ability, and so they cannot be directly applied to non-human animals. Several alternative measures have been developed to study intelligence in animals, relying on the observation of animals in natural situations or on behavioral tasks in experimental settings. The tasks focus on such things as innovation and problem solving, response to novelty, habit reversal and inhibition, and social learning and culture. A comprehensive assessment often includes a battery of tests involving several sorts of behavior.<ref>Tomasello, M., & Call, J. (1997). Primate cognition. Oxford University Press.</ref>
===Innovation & problem solving=== Innovation and problem solving tasks are the most widely used experimental measures of non-human intelligence. The same assessment often uses several tasks, which may involve [[memory]], [[spatial reasoning]], visual and auditory discrimination, and object manipulation.<ref>Banerjee, K., Chabris, C. F., Johnson, V. E., Lee, J. J., Tsao, F., & Hauser, M. D. (2009). General intelligence in another primate: individual differences across cognitive task performance in a New World monkey (Saguinus oedipus). PLoS One, 4(6), e5883.</ref> Innovation has often been observed in animals, typically involving novel solutions to everyday problems or the use of tools to achieve a goal. Instances include [[tool use by animals|termite fishing]] in [[chimpanzees]] or [[tool use by animals|nut cracking]] in [[robust capuchin monkey|robust capuchins]]. Such observations provide [[ecological validity|ecologically valid]] measures without the need for experimentation.<ref name="Reader" />
===Response to novelty===
Response to novelty is often used in intelligence measures in human infants.,<ref>Berg, C. A., & Sternberg, R. J. (1985). Response to novelty: Continuity versus discontinuity in the developmental course of intelligence. Advances in child development and behavior, 19, 1-47.</ref> for the amount of interest in novel objects and the time spent exploring a novel environment correlate with intelligence later in life. Responses to novelty in non-humans are thought to correlate similarly, though it can often be difficult to quantify this measure appropriately.<ref>Day, R. L., Coe, R. L., Kendal, J. R., & Laland, K. N. (2003). Neophilia, innovation and social learning: a study of intergeneric differences in callitrichid monkeys. Animal Behaviour, 65(3), 559-571.</ref>
===Habit reversal & inhibition===
[[Habit]] reversal and [[Social inhibition|inhibition]] are commonly used to test primate intelligence. These tasks require the animal to suppress a learned response or instinctive action in order to receive a reward. For example, in the detour problem, a food reward behind an obstacle must be retrieved by following an indirect route.<ref>Kohler, W. (1927). The mentality of apes (rev. edn). New York: Harcourt</ref> To do this, the subject must inhibit its tendency to move straight towards the goal.
===Social learning===
A number of intelligence tests for animals include [[social learning theory|social learning]]. The more an individual participates in and gains from social learning, the higher its intelligence is judged to be. Such data are most widely available for primates in social situations, often in wild populations, rather than experimental set-ups<ref name="Reader" /> Such observations are more [[ecological validity|ecologically valid]] than some other measures.<ref>Reader, S. M., & Biro, D. (2010). Experimental identification of social learning in wild animals. Learning & Behavior, 38(3), 265-283.</ref> One basis for their inclusion in IQ studies centers around the theory of [[cultural intelligence]].<ref name="van Schaik">van Schaik, C. P., & Burkart, J. M. (2011). Social learning and evolution: the cultural intelligence hypothesis. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences, 366(1567), 1008-1016.</ref><ref name="Herrmann">Herrmann, E., Call, J., Hernández-Lloreda, M. V., Hare, B., & Tomasello, M. (2007). Humans have evolved specialized skills of social cognition: the cultural intelligence hypothesis. science, 317(5843), 1360-1366.</ref>
==''g'' in non-human mammals==
A large portion of the research into non-human ''g'' factors has focused on mammals. Being mammals themselves, humans have a great deal in common with other mammals, sharing similarities in aspects such as [[physiology]] and [[neurochemistry]]. [[Social learning theory|Social learning]] and [[culture]] may have played a large role in the [[evolution of intelligence]] in humans<ref name="van Schaik" /><ref name="Herrmann" /> (including its factor structure) and as such it follows that other animals may have similar single-factor models of intelligence.
===Primates===
Due to their close [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] proximity to humans, [[primates]] ([[great apes]] in particular) have been the focus of a large part of the research into the prevalence of a ''g'' factor in non-human animals.
A [[meta-analysis]] of 4000 [[ethology|primate behaviour]] academic papers searching for instances of [[innovation]], [[social learning theory|social learning]], [[tool use]], and [[foraging|extractive foraging]] was conducted to investigate the components of these behaviours in 62 species of primates.<ref name="Reader"/> A [[Principal Components Analysis]] of these cognitive measures (as well as three socio-ecological variables, (diet breadth, percentage fruit in diet, and group size) revealed a single factor explaining 47% of the variance onto which the cognitive measures and diet breadth (somewhat) loaded. This would suggest that non-human primates, as a whole, have a ''g'' factor similar to that observed in humans.
===Rodents===
[[laboratory mouse|Mice]] and [[laboratory rat|rats]] have been used as [[model organisms]] in research for hundreds of years<ref>Fox, J. G., Barthold, S., Davisson, M., Newcomer, C. E., Quimby, F. W., & Smith, A. (2006). The Mouse in Biomedical Research: Normative biology, husbandry, and models (Vol. 3). Academic Press.</ref> and have been a staple of [[experimental psychology]] for decades. Both have been proposed as easily accessible models for studying ''g''.<ref name="Plomin" /><ref>Matzel, L. D., Han, Y. R., Grossman, H., Karnik, M. S., Patel, D., Scott, N., ... & Gandhi, C. C. (2003). Individual differences in the expression of a “general” learning ability in mice. The Journal of Neuroscience, 23(16), 6423-6433.</ref> The ''g'' factor loadings in [[Long-Evans]] rats has been shown to range from .43 to as high as .70 in cognitive ability tasks.<ref>Jensen, A. R. The ''g'' Factor: The Science of Mental Ability (Praeger, Westport, Connecticut, 1998).</ref> In mice, about 55-60% of the individual variance in tests of cognitive ability can be explained by ''g''.<ref>Locurto, C., & Durkin, E. Problem-solving and individual differences in mice (Mus musculus) using water reinforcement. J Comp Psychol.</ref><ref>Locurto, C. & Scanlon, C. Individual differences and a spatial learning factor in two strains of mice (Mus musculus). J. Comp. Psychol. 112, 344–352 (1998).</ref>
==Applications==
===Genetic research===
Non-human [[Scientific modelling|models]] of intelligence can be used in [[individual differences]] research for study designs that are difficult or [[unethical]] to perform using human subjects. Examples of this include [[experimental drug]] testing and [[genetics|multi-generational studies]] that would take a very long time in humans.
One such aspect of intelligence well suited for a non-human model is the experimental study of [[genetics|genetic]] aspects of ''g''. [[laboratory mouse|Mice]] are currently being considered as a potential model due to their widespread availability, detailed knowledge of their [[genome]], and the ease with which strains can be [[bred]] to exhibit individual differences in [[cognitive ability]].<ref name="Plomin" />
===Neuroscience===
Non-human models can also be used in [[neuroscience]] for [[neuroanatomical]] studies investigating intelligence and the influence of ''g'' on the neurological level. Rats have been used in experimental manipulations of intelligence using chemicals administered [[prenatal development (biology)|prenatally]].<ref name="Anderson" /> These effects are partially reversed by stimulation of [[neurology|neurological development]] and suggest that neuronal and synaptic numbers have an effect on ''g''.
==Criticism==
A 2012 study identifying individual chimpanzees that consistently performed highly on cognitive tasks found clusters of abilities instead of a general factor of intelligence.<ref>Herrmann, E., & Call, J. (2012). Are there geniuses among the apes?.Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences,367(1603), 2753-2761.</ref> This study used individual-based data and claim that their results are not directly comparable to previous studies using group data that have found evidence for ''g''. The authors propose a future research should test multiple individuals of multiple species on a variety of tasks to investigate this discrepancy.
==See also== *[[g factor (psychometrics)|''g'' factor]] *[[Intelligence]] *[[Animal cognition]] *[[Primate cognition]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:Animal intelligence]] [[Category:Psychometrics]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} [[File:Get your sexy back logo.jpg|frame|1675px|right|The initiative's logo]] "'''Get Your Sexy Back'''" (GYSB) is a youth-led anti-binge drinking initiative that aims to promote responsible drinking behaviour, by raising the [[social currency]] of moderation. The first such initiative in Singapore, the programme was launched in December 2007 and spearheaded by [[Asia Pacific Breweries]] (APBS), an Asian Brewery listed on the [[Singapore Exchange]].<ref>[http://www.asiaone.com/Health/News/Story/A1Story20080211-49017.html Anti-binge drinking campaign: Get serious] Asiaone News, 11 February 2008.</ref>
A recurring message of the campaign is that consuming 5 or more units of alcohol at a single sitting constitutes [[binge drinking]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.soshiok.sg/articles/9644 |publisher=SoShiok.com |title=Young and Smashed |date=4 June 2008 |df=dmy }}{{dead link|date=January 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> This is only one possible definition of binge drinking and other standards have been adopted by anti-binge drinking campaigns in countries like Australia by the [[National Health and Medical Research Council]]. In 2008, GYSB released the findings of a survey into the drinking habits of young adults in Singapore aged between 18 and 25. The findings of this survey showed an increasing prevalence of binge drinking among youths,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/383350/1/.html |publisher=Channel NewsAsia |title=Survey shows 73% of young club-goers binge drink at least once a month|date=16 October 2008}}</ref> and a greater tendency towards excessive drinking among female drinkers.<ref>[http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/396865/1/.html Binge drinking an "emerging issue in Singapore, says HPB], Channel NewsAsia, 7 December 2008.</ref>
== History ==
Get Your Sexy Back was originally conceived by four students from the [[Nanyang Technological University]] (NTU), as part of a school project. The students identified several factors responsible for [[binge drinking]] among youths in Singapore and approached APBS for support. The programme was subsequently adopted by APBS as part of its [[corporate social responsibility]] initiatives in Singapore.
GYSB was first launched in December 2007<ref>[http://marketing-interactive.com/news/4477 Moderate drinking keeps you sexy] Marketing-Interactive, 11 January 2008.</ref> with the aim of encouraging responsible drinking behaviour among young adults from 18 – 25 years old by raising the social currency of [[moderation]]. The programme engages its target audience through various youth-related activities and platforms, broadly spanning the areas of music, fashion, sports and friendship.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.youth.sg/content/view/6234/66/ |publisher = Youth.sg |title = Get Your Sexy Back is back |date = 18 October 2008 |access-date = 15 April 2009 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090901051435/http://www.youth.sg/content/view/6234/66 |archive-date = 1 September 2009 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> GYSB's slogan: “It’s not the drinking, it’s how you’re drinking” was adapted with permission from a New Zealand campaign by the Alcohol Advisory Council of New Zealand (ALAC).<ref>[http://www.alac.org.nz/MediaRelease.aspx?PostingID=3109 Alcohol Advisory Council of New Zealand (ALAC)]</ref>
The programme has been present at a number of youth-oriented events, particularly in conjunction with tertiary student associations and national youth bodies. These events include the NTU Surf n Sweat, National Vertical Marathon, the Seventeen magazine Queen of Queens and the [[Singapore Management University]] (SMU) Waikiki. In partnering these events, the programme has frequently drawn on support from other corporate partners including Singaporean fashion label NewUrbanMale.com, outdoor media specialists [[Clear Channel]] Singapore, as well as convenience chains Cheers and [[7-Eleven]].
The campaign has also been actively involved in the recruitment of youth volunteers and volunteer ambassadors to pledge their support for the cause of moderate drinking. Recruitment of volunteers has mainly been conducted online via the campaign website, in the various tertiary [[campuses]], as well as at roadshows held at shopping malls.
In February 2010, an article in the TODAY newspaper cited GYSB as an example of a highly successful youth-oriented campaign. The article also stated that more and more youths have been pledging their support for moderate drinking since the launch of GYSB in 2007.<ref>[http://www.todayonline.com/Business/Impact/EDC100209-0000046/Young-guns "Young Guns"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622000014/http://www.todayonline.com/Business/Impact/EDC100209-0000046/Young-guns |date=22 June 2011 }}, Today Newspaper, 9 February 2010</ref>
==Platforms== The GYSB programme encourages youths to live active, healthy social lives by engaging in activities other than [[binge drinking]]. It has grouped these activities into four main youth-oriented platforms.
===Music=== To coincide with the relaunch of GYSB on 16 October 2008,<ref>[http://www.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne%2BNews/Singapore/Story/A1Story20081219-108979.html Cheers! Drink moderately and Get Your Sexy Back!], Asiaone News, 19 December 2008.</ref> singer-songwriter Jillian-Marie Thomas, also a volunteer ambassador, wrote and composed a theme song for the GYSB programme.
GYSB also entered into a collaboration with [[Sony Music Entertainment]], producing a set of GYSB CD inserts which were released together with the launch of the 'Capricorn' album from Taiwanese singer [[Jay Chou]] in October 2008.
On 4 April 2009, GYSB staged a concert at The Heeren shopping mall featuring a Singaporean band, "Da Feng Chui". The band, who was an on [[MediaCorp Channel U|Channel U]]'s Superband 2008 talent-search, and also launched their debut album in conjunction with the concert dedicating one of the songs on the album to the Get Your Sexy Back campaign.
On 9 December 2009, GYSB staged a music concert in support of responsible drinking at popular nightspot Velvet Underground. The concert featured regional superstar JJ Lin, SuperBand 2008 runners-up Da Feng Chui, Project Superstar alumni Chen Diya and Carrie Yeo, homegrown singer/songwriter Jillian Marie Thomas, and indie-alternative band en(x).<ref name>{{cite web |url=http://blog.omy.sg/blogclub/2009/12/16/get-your-sexy-back-by-drinking-responsibly/ |title=Get Your Sexy Back, by drinking responsibly |date=16 December 2009|publisher=OMY}}</ref> All proceeds from the concert were donated to sporting clubs and student associations from Singapore's three main universities. Also announced at the concert were a new range of GYSB T-shirts, designed by local fashionistas, designers and fashion bloggers; and the details of a new membership benefits programme dubbed the GYSB Friends Card.
===Fashion=== Singaporean fashion and lifestyle label NewUrbanMale.com (NUM) designed an exclusive range of 'NUMXGYSB' T-shirts<ref>[http://www.todayonline.com/articles/282201.asp "Drinking’s not Sexy"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018210922/http://www.todayonline.com/articles/282201.asp |date=18 October 2008 }}. ''TODAY'', 18 October 2008.</ref> in October 2008. The shirts, each bearing the [[slogan]] "Two beers or not two beers" were retailed at selected NUM stores island-wide and were designed by NUM founder Shenzi Chua who has likened the slogan to a question on the difficult choices confronting youths when dealing with alcohol.
In December 2009, GYSB launched the third generation of GYSB T-shirts with a collection of three designs by local fashion bloggers Dinnie & Ridhwan, design student Sid Lim and T-shirt printing specialists Ministry of Press.
===Sports=== On 18 Oct 2008, GYSB teamed up with Nanyang Technological University (NTU) Sports Club to reach out to students at the NTU Street Challenge, the university's largest annual on-campus sporting event.
GYSB was also supported by the National Vertical Marathon 2009, Singapore Management University (SMU) Surf n Sweat 2009, SMU Waikiki, Freshmen Sports Orientation Camp and Sports Fiesta.
===Friends=== In 2007, the student founders of GYSB created a group page on the popular [[social media]] platform, Facebook to serve as an avenue where like-minded youths could come together and share their thoughts and experiences on moderate drinking.
In April 2009, a group of [[National University of Singapore]] (NUS) students, created and distributed a game via Facebook called "GYSB Matching Fury" as a way of spreading the message of moderate drinking via [[social networks]].
In December 2009, GYSB announced the launch of a membership benefits programme called the GYSB Friends Card. Given away free to programme supporters, the card gives discounts and other privileges at retailers across Singapore. Current commercial partners include Leftfoot, Times the Bookshop and Ministry of Press.

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:H2NO}} '''H2NO''' refers to an [[upselling]] campaign by [[Coca-Cola]] to dissuade consumers from ordering [[tap water]] drinks at restaurants, and to instead order more profitable [[soft drink]]s, non-carbonated beverages, or [[bottled water]]. The campaign's title, H2NO, reflects the program's purpose, which is to have customers say ''No'' to ''H2O'', the [[chemical formula]] for water. The program taught waiters how to use "suggestive selling techniques" to offer a variety of alternative beverages when diners asked for water.{{cite news| title=Forget Tap Water, Serve Coke, Restaurants Told |publisher=[[Daily Mail]] |date=September 5, 2001 |last=Willey |first=Jo |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-77850308.html}}{{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}} In July 2001, a link to a story about the program's success at [[Olive Garden]] was posted to [[Cockeyed.com]]. The link was reposted around the internet, until the story was taken down by Coca-Cola on August 2, 2001, for fears it might be misinterpreted. On August 20, 2001, the story was covered by ''[[The New York Times]]'',https://www.nytimes.com/2001/09/02/weekinreview/word-for-word-deep-water-just-say-no-to-h20-unless-it-s-coke-s-own-brew.html and subsequently by a number of news providers. The campaign ran only in the United States.{{cite news|last=Rowan|first=David|title=Coke's war on water; Drinks giant trains waiters to boost sales in 'H2No' campaign.|url=http://business.highbeam.com/5729/article-1G1-77822850/coke-war-water-drinks-giant-trains-waiters-boost-sales|accessdate=29 August 2012|newspaper=[[Evening Standard]]|date=September 4, 2001 |page=21}}{{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}} ==Discovery and Coca-Cola response== The H2NO campaign had been conducted through an Internet memo to distributors and restaurants.{{cite news|title=Water, please |publisher=Bangor Daily News (ME)|date=August 31, 2001 |page=12}} In July 2001, Rob Cockerham, a [[graphic designer]] in [[Sacramento]], came across the Olive Garden success story following an online search, and posted a link to the story on his website, [[Cockeyed.com]]. In an interview with ''The New York Times'', Cockerham noted how "I had to assure more than one person that this was not a prank, and that it was a real article from Coca-Cola." On August 2, 2001, about a week after the success story link was posted to Cockeyed.com, the Coca-Cola portal was closed.{{cite web|title=Coca-Cola success stories|url=http://www.stayfreemagazine.org/public/coke.html|publisher=[[Stay Free!]]|accessdate=29 August 2012}} Polly Howes, a spokeswoman for Coca-Cola, stated that the story might be misinterpreted by "folks who aren't in a sales-related business" and that the site was due to be dismantled.{{cite news| title=Having Customers Say No to Tap Water |author=David F. Gallagher |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=August 20, 2001 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/08/20/technology/20COKE.html}} Following the ''New York Times'' article, the story was covered by major news providers, including ''[[Daily Mail]]'', ''[[Sunday Herald Sun]]'', ''[[Evening Standard]]'' and was featured on ''[[The Glass House (2001 TV series)|The Glass House]].''{{Cite episode |title= Richard Glover and Sarah Kendall |series= The Glass House |serieslink=The Glass House (2001 TV series) |season=1 |number=8 }} ==Olive Garden success story== {{ external media | align = right | width = 258px | image1 = [http://imgur.com/a/mJFpZ H2NO campaign screenshots], [[Imgur]] }} In a success story on Coca-Cola's online public relations portal, entitled "The Olive Targets Tap Water & WINS", Coca-Cola described the purpose, implementation, and success in reducing "tap water incidence". Coca-Cola stated that customers chose tap water out of habit, and that selling alternative beverages would increase guest satisfaction:
Water. It's necessary to sustain life, but to many Casual Dining restaurant chains it contributes to a dull dining experience for the customer. Many customers choose tap water not because they enjoy it, but because it is what they always have drunk in the past. In response, some restaurant chains are implementing programs to help train crews to sell alternative choices to tap water, like soft drinks and non-carbonated beverages, with the goal of increasing overall guest satisfaction.{{cite web|title=The Olive Garden Targets Tap Water & WINS|url=http://customer.coca-cola.com/html/olivegard_article_ss.html|publisher=[[Coca-Cola]]|accessdate=29 August 2012|archiveurl=http://www.stayfreemagazine.org/public/coke.html|archivedate=August 1, 2001|page=1}}
[[Olive Garden]]'s stated goal was "to influence customers to abandon their default choice of tap water and experience other beverage choices to improve their dining experience".{{cite web|title=The Olive Garden Targets Tap Water & WINS|url=http://customer.coca-cola.com/html/olivegard_article_ss2.html|publisher=[[Coca-Cola]]|accessdate=29 August 2012|archiveurl=http://www.stayfreemagazine.org/public/coke.html|archivedate=August 1, 2001|page=2}} {{quote box |quote = According to reports in the US, the first shots in the [[war against water]] were fired in [[Olive Garden]] restaurants. |source = —"Coke says no to H2O", ''[[Sunday Herald Sun]]'' (2001){{cite news|title=Coke says no to H2O |publisher=Sunday Herald Sun |location=Melbourne, Australia |date=September 9, 2001| page=25}} |width = 30% |align= right |bgcolor= #c6dbf7 }} The Olive Garden suffered from a "high water incidence rate" and "wanted their restaurant crews to emphasize the broad array of alternative beverage selections available" so as "to influence customers to abandon their default choice of tap water and experience other beverage choices to improve their dining experience." In response, the Coca-Cola USA-Fountain offered the tap water reduction program H2NO. The H2NO program featured "beverage suggestive selling techniques (a technique used when a server suggests a profitable beverage in place of water to the customer during the ordering process)." Alternative beverages including soft drinks, non-carbonated beverages and alcohol would be offered which would lead to higher "overall check averages" and greater profits. To further improve the effectiveness of the program, the "Olive Garden developed an employee incentive contest linked to H2NO with CCUSA-Fountain called 'Just Say No to H2O.'" The success story noted how "because of its own successful campaign against water, The Olive Garden has recently sent a powerful message to the entire restaurant industry - less water and more beverage choices mean happier customers" stating how:
When the contest was completed, almost all participating restaurants realized significant increases in beverage sales and reduced levels of tap water incidence - a strong indication that Olive Garden restaurants succeeded in enhancing the customer's dining experience. And perhaps most importantly, Olive Garden expects to see this trend continue as the skills learned become part of the crew's everyday interaction with restaurant customers.
==Criticism== {{quote box |quote = In this age of branding, even plain old milk needs a big ad campaign and celebrity endorsements. But another popular beverage, tap water, has no such support -- a tactical misstep that has left it vulnerable to aggressive competitors like the Coca-Cola Company. |source = —"'Just Say No to H20' (Unless It's Coke's Own Brew)", ''[[The New York Times]]'' (2001){{cite news|title='Just Say No to H20' (Unless It's Coke's Own Brew) |author=David F. Gallagher |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=September 2, 2001 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/09/02/weekinreview/02WORD.html}} |width = 30% |align= right |bgcolor= #c6dbf7 }} The program and Olive Garden success story were widely ridiculed.{{cite news|title=Replacing water with Coke?|url=http://journalrecord.com/2001/08/21/replacing-water-with-coke063-business-world/|accessdate=29 August 2012|newspaper=[[The Journal Record]]|date=August 21, 2001 }}{{Subscription required}}{{cite web|title=The Olive Garden just says no to H2O!|url=http://www.metafilter.com/9399/The-Olive-Garden-just-says-no-to-H2O|publisher=[[MetaFilter]]}} On August 22, 2001, [[Peter Gleick]], the director of the [[Pacific Institute]], wrote a [[letter to the editor]] of ''The New York Times'', criticizing the campaign, noting how "both PepsiCo and Coca-Cola use perfectly potable tap water as the source of their bottled waters, Aquafina and Dasani. I guess tap water is O.K., if we can be made to pay for it."{{cite news|last=Gleick|first=Peter|title=Tap Water, in a Bottle|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/08/24/opinion/l-tap-water-in-a-bottle-842370.html|accessdate=29 August 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 22, 2001}} In a report by [[Corporate Accountability International]], ''Tapping Congress to Get Off the Bottle'', the report criticized the campaign as part of how "bottlers have employed a range of marketing tactics that have overtly disparaged the tap."{{cite web|title=Tapping Congress to Get Off the Bottle: Renewing our public water systems begins by turning off the spigot to bottled water |publisher=[[Corporate Accountability International]] |work=[[Think Outside the Bottle]] |url=http://www.stopcorporateabuse.org/sites/default/files/resources/tappingcongresstogetoffthebottle_0.pdf |date=February 2011 |page=5}} The Olive Garden success story and the H2NO program have been cited in literature as examples of the [[Bottled water in the United States|bottled water industry]]'s aggressive advertising campaigns which views tap water as an impediment to increased profits.{{cite book|last=McLaren|first=edited by Carrie|title=Ad nauseam : a survivor's guide to American consumer culture|year=2009|publisher=Faber and Faber|location=New York|isbn=9780865479876|pages=206–207|edition=1st|author2=Torchinsky, Jason|chapter=Coca-Cola and the Case of the Disappearing Water Glass}}{{cite book|last=Wolff|first=Kimberley De|title=H₂O to go marketing and materiality in the normalization of bottled water.|publisher=[[Queen's University]] |location=Ottawa|isbn=9780494372746|pages=81–84|url=https://qspace.library.queensu.ca/jspui/bitstream/1974/860/1/De%20Wolff_Kimberley_200709_MA.pdf|date=September 2007|work=Master's Thesis}}{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Mark|title=Bottled Water: Why Is It so Big? Causes for the Rapid Growth of Bottled Water Industries|url=https://digital.library.txstate.edu/bitstream/handle/10877/3296/fulltext.pdf|work=Honors Thesis|publisher=Texas State University|accessdate=29 August 2012|pages=17–18|date=May 2006}}{{cite journal|last=Gerstein|first=Hilary|title=Nor Any Drop to Drink: A Systems Approach to Water in America|journal=Momentum|date=April 18, 2012|volume=1|series=1|url=http://repository.upenn.edu/momentum/vol1/iss1/21/mentum|accessdate=29 August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121212184508/http://repository.upenn.edu/momentum/vol1/iss1/21/mentum|archivedate=12 December 2012|df=}}{{cite book|last1=Gottlieb|first1=Robert|last2=Joshi|first2=Anupama|title=Food Justice|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LidIhmYywz0C&pg=PA53|accessdate=29 August 2012|date=31 October 2010|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=978-0-262-07291-5|page=53}}{{cite book|last=Schor|first=Juliet|title=Sustainable Planet: Roadmaps for the Twenty-first Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3OoZU0d_IvAC&pg=PA1|accessdate=29 August 2012|date=20 January 2003|publisher=Beacon Press|isbn=978-0-8070-0455-5|page=1}}{{cite book|author=John Trimbur|title=The call to write|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Xk6lGaMvswC|accessdate=29 August 2012|date=10 August 2004|publisher=Pearson Longman|isbn=978-0-321-20305-2|pages=12–13}}{{cite book|last1=Clarke|first1=Tony|last2=Alternatives|first2=Canadian Centre for Policy|title=Inside the Bottle: An Exposé of the Bottled Water Industry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8MtaAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=29 August 2012|date=30 August 2007|publisher=Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives|isbn=978-0-88627-536-5|pages=90–91}} ==See also== * [[Nestlé boycott]] (targeting that company's promotion of breast milk substitutes) * [http://www.tapsydney.com.au/ Tap Sydney] - a [[Sydney Water]] initiative to increase the choice of tap water over bottled beverages. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Advertising in the United States]] [[Category:Promotional campaigns by Coca-Cola]] [[Category:Drinking water]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{ infobox robot | name = Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL) | logo = | logosize = | image = Hybrid_Assistive_Limb.jpg | imsize = | alt = | caption = A man wearing a 2005 prototype version of the HAL suit (left) | manufacturer = [[Cyberdyne Inc. (Japanese company)|Cyberdyne]] | country = Japan | year_of_creation = 1997 (earliest prototype)
2012 (full HAL-5 suit) | type = [[Powered exoskeleton]] | purpose = Medical / [[search and rescue]] | derived_from = | replaced_by = | website = {{url|http://www.cyberdyne.jp/english/index.html|cyberdyne.jp}} }} The '''Hybrid Assistive Limb''' (also known as '''HAL''') is a [[powered exoskeleton]] suit developed by Japan's [[Tsukuba University]] and the robotics company [[Cyberdyne Inc. (Japanese company)|Cyberdyne]]. It is designed to support and expand the physical capabilities of its users, particularly people with physical disabilities. There are two primary versions of the system: HAL 3, which only provides leg function, and HAL 5, which is a full-body exoskeleton for the arms, legs, and torso. In 2011, Cyberdyne and Tsukuba University jointly announced that hospital trials of the full HAL suit would begin in 2012, with tests to continue until 2014 or 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20110311/business/robot-suit-offers-glimmer-of-hope-to-the-paralysed |title=Robot suit offers glimmer of hope to the paralysed |work=Times of Malta |date=11 March 2011 |accessdate=26 August 2012}} By October 2012, HAL suits were in use by 130 different medical institutions across Japan. In February 2013, the HAL system became the first powered exoskeleton to receive global safety certification.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gOWaBQ0XAy5M5crIrhO2uyTSyvEA?docId=CNG.722c21ce71c2b2203f35cd3432c15546.631|title=Japan robot suit gets global safety certificate|publisher=AFP via Google|date=27 February 2013|accessdate=28 February 2013}} In August 2013, HAL received [[European Commission|EC]] certification for clinical use in Europe as the world's first non-surgical medical treatment robot.{{cite web|url=http://www.tuv.com/jp/japan/about_us_jp/press_2/news_1/news_contentjp_en_168321.html|title=TÜV Rheinland Issues EC certificate for Cyberdyne’s Medical Robot Suit HAL®|publisher=TÜV Rheinland|date=7 August 2013|accessdate=14 August 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.japanpolicyforum.jp/en/archives/economy/pt20131125174131.html|title=Global Companies from Japan|publisher=Weekly Toyo Keizai|date=14 September 2013|accessdate=17 March 2014}} In addition to its medical applications, the HAL exoskeleton has been used in construction and disaster response work. ==History== The first HAL prototype was proposed by [[Yoshiyuki Sankai]], a professor at Tsukuba University. Fascinated with robots since he was in the third grade, Sankai had striven to make a robotic suit in order “to support humans.”{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fy7ipDAyXtI |title=Cyberdyne power suit |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=31 July 2009 |accessdate=26 August 2012}} In 1989, after receiving his Ph.D. in robotics, he began the development of HAL. Sankai spent three years, from 1990 to 1993, mapping out the [[neurons]] that govern leg movement. It took him and his team an additional four years to make a prototype of the hardware.{{cite web|url=http://web-japan.org/nipponia/nipponia38/en/feature/feature02.html|title=HAL, a friend for people with disabilities|work=Nipponia|publisher=Web Japan|date=15 September 2006|accessdate=16 July 2013}} The third HAL prototype, developed in the early 2000s, was attached to a computer. Its battery alone weighed nearly {{convert|22|kg|lb}} and required two helpers to put on, making it very impractical. By contrast, later HAL-5 model weighs only {{convert|10|kg|lb}} and has its battery and control computer strapped around the waist of the wearer. Cyberdyne began renting the HAL suit out for medical purposes in 2008. By October 2012, over 300 HAL suits were in use by 130 medical facilities and [[nursing home]]s across Japan. The suit is available for institutional rental, in Japan only, for a monthly fee of US$2,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/robots-to-the-rescue-as-an-aging-japan-looks-for-help/story-e6frg6so-1226494698495|title=Robots to the rescue as an aging Japan looks for help|work=[[The Australian]]|date=13 October 2012|accessdate=17 October 2012}} In December 2012, Cyberdyne was certified [[ISO 13485]] – an international quality standard for design and manufacture of medical devices – by [[UL (safety organization)|Underwriters Laboratories]].{{cite web|url=http://database.ul.com/certs/PDWS.A18103.pdf|title=The design, manufacture and servicing of wearable lower limb exoskeleton devices for rehabilitation and physical training|publisher=Underwriters Laboratories|date=11 December 2012|accessdate=16 July 2013 |format=pdf}} In late February 2013, the HAL suit received a global safety certificate, becoming the first powered exoskeleton to do so. In August 2013, the suit received an EC certificate, permitting its use for medical purposes in Europe as the first medical treatment robot of its kind. ==Design and mechanics== When a person attempts to move their body, nerve signals are sent from the brain to the muscles through the motor neurons, moving the [[musculoskeletal system]]. When this happens, small [[biosignal]]s can be detected on the surface of the skin. The HAL suit registers these signals through a sensor attached to the skin of the wearer. Based on the signals obtained, the power unit moves the joint to support and amplify the wearer's motion. The HAL suit possesses a cybernic control system consisting of both a user-activated “voluntary control system" known as Cybernic Voluntary Control (CVC) and a “robotic autonomous control system" known as Cybernic Autonomous Control (CAC) for automatic motion support.{{cite journal|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1163/156855307781746061#.Uybvcl46xfY|title=Intention-based walking support for paraplegia patients with Robot Suit HAL|work=Advanced Robotics. 2007, vol. 21, pp1441-1469.|publisher=Taylor & Francis|year=2007|accessdate=17 March 2014|doi=10.1163/156855307781746061}}{{cite web|url=http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2377/13/141|title=Pilot study of locomotion improvement using hybrid assistive limb in chronic stroke patients|work=BMC Neurology. 2013, vol. 13, p141.|publisher=BMC|year=2013|accessdate=17 March 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://cybernics.tsukuba.ac.jp/english/research/index.html|title=Research Program Cybernics University of Tsukuba|work=Global COE Program, Cybernics|publisher=University of Tsukuba|date=1 April 2007|accessdate=17 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027145913/http://www.cybernics.tsukuba.ac.jp/english/research/index.html|archivedate=27 October 2014|df=dmy-all}} ==Users== HAL is designed to assist the disabled and elderly in their daily tasks, but can also be used to support workers with physically demanding jobs such as disaster rescue or construction. HAL is mainly used by disabled patients in hospitals, and can be modified so that patients can use it for longer-term rehabilitation. In addition, scientific studies have shown that, in combination with specially-created therapeutic games, powered exoskeletons like the HAL-5 can stimulate cognitive activities and help disabled children walk while playing.{{cite web|url=http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=646269.684335 |title=Computers for the Development of Young Disabled Children – Introduction to the Special Thematic Session|year=2002|publisher=ACM.org|accessdate=26 November 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.abledata.com/abledata.cfm?pageid=160377&ksectionid=160164&atlitid=198393 |title=Influence of Virtual Reality Soccer Game on Walking Performance in Robotic Assisted Gait Training for Children|publisher=AbleData.com|date=April 2010|accessdate=26 November 2012}} Further scientific studies have shown that [[HAL Therapy]] can be effectively used for rehabilitation after [[spinal cord injury]] or [[stroke]].{{cite web|url=http://walk-again.com/research/|title= Current scientific studies to exoskeleton therapy with Hybrid Assistive Limb|publisher=WALK AGAIN Center|accessdate=2016-01-28}} During the 2011 [[Consumer Electronics Show]], it was announced that the [[United States]] government had expressed interest in purchasing HAL suits.{{cite web|url=http://mylifescoop.com/2011/01/12/ces-spotlight-japanese-robot-exoskeletons/|title=CES Spotlight: Japanese Robot Exoskeletons|date=12 January 2011|accessdate=28 February 2013}} In March 2011, Cyberdyne presented a legs-only HAL version for the disabled, health care professionals and factory workers.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2011/03/15/cyberdyne-demos-lower-body-hal-exoskeleton-for-helping-the-disab/|title=Cyberdyne demos lower-body HAL exoskeleton for helping the disabled, not eradicating mankind (video)|date=15 March 2011|accessdate=28 February 2013}} In November 2011, HAL was selected to be used for cleanup work at the site of the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|Fukushima nuclear accident]].{{cite web|url=http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/2011/11/09/robotic-exoskeletons-from-cyberdyne-could-help-workers-clean-up-fukushima-nuclear-mess/|title=Robotic Exoskeletons from Cyberdyne Could Help Workers Clean Up Fukushima Nuclear Mess|work=[[Scientific American]]|date=9 November 2011|accessdate=27 November 2011}} During the Japan Robot Week exhibition in Tokyo in October 2012, a redesigned version of HAL was presented, designed specifically for the Fukushima cleanup.{{cite web|url=http://neurogadget.com/2012/10/18/new-hal-exoskeleton-brain-controlled-full-body-suit-to-be-used-in-fukushima-cleanup/5612|title=New HAL Exoskeleton: Brain-Controlled Full Body Suit to Be Used In Fukushima Cleanup|publisher=Neurogadget.com|date=18 October 2012|accessdate=22 October 2012}} In March 2013, ten Japanese hospitals conducted clinical tests of the newer legs-only HAL system.{{cite web|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/economy/technology/AJ201302090058|title=Hospitals to test robot suit to help patients walk|work=The Asahi Shimbun|date=9 February 2013|accessdate=17 February 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213231852/http://ajw.asahi.com/article/economy/technology/AJ201302090058|archivedate=13 February 2013|df=dmy-all}} In late 2014, HAL exoskeletons modified for construction use entered service with the Japanese construction contractor [[Obayashi Corporation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.itworld.com/article/2835074/robotics/smart-walkers-lead-the-way-for-japanese-eldercare-robots.html|title=Smart walkers lead the way for Japanese elder-care robots|publisher=ITWorld.com|date=16 October 2014|accessdate=22 October 2014}} ==See also== {{Portal|Robotics|Disability}} *[[Atlas (robot)]], a humanoid robot designed for search and rescue *[[Ekso Bionics]] *[[ReWalk]] *[[Vanderbilt exoskeleton]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.cyberdyne.jp/english/index.html}} {{en icon}} {{jp icon}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.spectrum.ieee.org/oct05/1901|title=The Rise of the Body Bots|work=IEEE Spectrum|date=October 2005|accessdate=18 February 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504142710/http://www.spectrum.ieee.org/oct05/1901|archivedate=4 May 2009|df=dmy-all}} * [http://walk-again.com/ WALK AGAIN Center] — HAL Training Center [[Category:Assistive technology]] [[Category:Disability robots]] [[Category:Japanese inventions]] [[Category:Medical robotics]] [[Category:Rehabilitation robots]] [[Category:Robotic exoskeletons]] [[Category:Robots of Japan]] [[Category:2000s robots]] [[Category:2012 in science]] [[Category:2012 robots]]
